stem: ABG: pH 7.10, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, HCO3- 18 mEq/L. What best describes this pattern?
rationale_correct: The pH is severely acidemic. PaCO2 is elevated and HCO3- is low, indicating two primary acidifying processes occurring simultaneously.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because both CO2 retention and bicarbonate loss are present. | B: HCO3- would be elevated, not decreased. | C: PaCO2 would be lower if compensating. | D: Chronic would show elevated HCO3-.
keywords_to_notice: very low pH | high PaCO2 | low HCO3-
common_trap: Assuming compensation when values move in opposite acidifying directions.
exam_logic: If both variables worsen pH in same direction, think mixed disorder.

stem: ABG: pH 7.52, PaCO2 28 mm Hg, HCO3- 23 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated pH with low PaCO2 and near-normal HCO3- indicates acute respiratory alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct acute pattern. | B: Chronic would show lower HCO3-. | C: HCO3- not elevated. | D: No dual primary process.
keywords_to_notice: high pH | low PaCO2 | near normal HCO3-

sub_concept: Metabolic acidosis with respiratory acidosis overlap
stem: ABG: pH 7.22, PaCO2 55 mm Hg, HCO3- 21 mEq/L. Using Winter formula, expected PaCO2 is approximately 1.5(21)+8=39.5. What does this indicate?
rationale_correct: Measured PaCO2 (55) is far above expected (≈40), indicating additional respiratory acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because compensation is inadequate. | B: Compensation would match expected value. | C: PaCO2 elevated not decreased. | D: pH abnormal.
exam_logic: Use Winter formula to detect mixed disorder.

stem: ABG: pH 7.36, PaCO2 65 mm Hg, HCO3- 36 mEq/L. What is most accurate?
option_a: Chronic respiratory acidosis with metabolic compensation
rationale_correct: Near-normal pH with markedly elevated PaCO2 and high HCO3- indicates chronic compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct chronic pattern. | B: Acute would not elevate HCO3- this much. | C: PaCO2 elevated. | D: Values move in compensatory direction.
keywords_to_notice: near normal pH | high PaCO2 | high HCO3-
common_trap: Labeling it acute due to high CO2.
exam_logic: Magnitude of HCO3- rise suggests chronicity.

stem: ABG: pH 7.50, PaCO2 44 mm Hg, HCO3- 34 mEq/L. What is the primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Elevated pH with elevated bicarbonate indicates metabolic alkalosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct because HCO3- elevated. | B: PaCO2 not decreased. | C: No conflicting primary process. | D: pH abnormal.

sub_concept: Anion gap interpretation with albumin normal
stem: Lab values: Na 138, Cl 104, HCO3- 12. What is the anion gap and interpretation?
rationale_correct: AG = 138 − (104+12)=22, elevated indicating high gap acidosis.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct math and interpretation. | B: Arithmetic incorrect. | C: Alkalosis not supported. | D: Not correct calculation.

stem: A patient has AG 28 with normal baseline of 12. What is delta gap?
rationale_correct: Delta gap equals measured AG minus normal AG: 28 − 12 = 16.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct calculation. | B: Confuses baseline. | C: Uses full AG. | D: Arithmetic error.
exam_logic: Delta gap helps assess mixed disorders.

stem: A patient is somnolent after opioid administration. ABG shows pH 7.28, PaCO2 60 mm Hg, HCO3- 26 mEq/L. What is most appropriate immediate action?
rationale_correct: Opioid-induced hypoventilation causes acute respiratory acidosis requiring ventilatory support.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct airway priority. | B: Not indicated. | C: Does not correct ventilation problem. | D: Oxygen does not eliminate CO2.

stem: ABG: pH 7.29, PaCO2 30 mm Hg, HCO3- 14 mEq/L. Lactate elevated. What is primary disorder?
rationale_correct: Low HCO3- with acidemia indicates metabolic acidosis. Low PaCO2 reflects compensation.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct primary process. | B: pH not alkalemic. | C: Not supported. | D: HCO3- low not elevated.

stem: ABG: pH 7.40, PaCO2 40 mm Hg, PaO2 50 mm Hg on room air. What does this indicate?
rationale_correct: Normal pH and PaCO2 indicate adequate ventilation. Low PaO2 indicates isolated oxygenation defect.
rationale_why_others_wrong: A: Correct separation of functions. | B: CO2 normal. | C: No metabolic disturbance. | D: PaO2 abnormal.
